dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET, MORNING
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA moves along a typical suburban street in an AERIAL SHOT, showing bright and well kept home after home Finally, we focus on two homes. One house is orthadox suburban, littered with pink flamingos and lawn jockeys. The other could use a coat of paint and some gardening repairs. We dwell on the better of the two homes for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM, MORNING
dialogues.text: "BIG" RUSS JOHNSON slowly cracks his eyes open as a stead "clang-clang-clanging" shatters the silence of the bedroo he shares with his wife, MAE. Russ is a gruff, self-made man, the president of his own construction company (Olympian Construction--We Build The Bigger and Better), Russ admires hard work and doesn't - trust people who read newspapers that don't contain a comics page. Like many Americans, he's impressed by appearances. If it's big, it has to be great. Mae is a quiet, but strong woman. She winds up, doing mos of the child-rearing in the home and, at times, treats Ru like her biggest, most problematic child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ staggers to the bedroom window and gazes down into h backyard.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHNSON BACKYARD, MORNING
dialogues.text: There, his ten-year-old identical twin sons, RON and DON, are busy pitching a tent to spend the weekend in. The twi are gung-ho Cub Scouts with great imaginations. To them, the neatly-kept grassy yard, with its ceramic animals, is jungle. Although identical in appearance, Ron and Don are opposites. Ron has a mischievous streak as deep as the Grand Canyon while Don is the more responsible of the two

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM, MORNING
dialogues.text: Big Russ gapes at the twins, checking his watch.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: What are you two doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C) Don freezes. Ron continues banging merrily away.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Pitching a tent, dad. BIG RUSS (resigned) Don't you know I'm sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: But you're talking to us, dad. You look wide awake. Doesn't, he Don? DON (sotto, exasperated) Ron! Ron smiles innocently at his father. Big Russ slams the window down.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEDROOM, MORNING
dialogues.text: Big Russ bites his lip and walks back towards the bed.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Everybody in this house is a comedian.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Except you, dear.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Darn right. The clanging continues. Big Russ winces.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: They're only children.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Hitler was a child once, He crawls back under the covers. MAE (smiling sweetly) As long as you're up, why don't you make some coffee? Big Russ stares at her, perplexed. She smiles brightly at him. He's beaten. He sighs and gets out of bed, grabbing his favorite, battered Olympian Construction cap (it has picture of Hercules on it, with a big #1) down over his head with a sharp tug.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: INT, HALLWAY, MORNING
dialogues.text: Big Russ stumbles into the hall, still sleepy. He

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 3
dialogues.text: “) encounters his oldest son, "LITTLE" RUSS, in the hall. looking and clean-cut, "Little" Russ is a strong but slightly diminutive fifteen year old. His dead is constantly pushing him to overexcell. "Little" Russ doesn mind. He's a jock but not a typical one. He's quiet and, fact, more than a tad self-conscious about his short stature.

dialogues.speaker: . BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Why don't you pump some iron, son. Get in shape for football practice.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Uh, dad...? Big Russ doesn't give his son a chance to speak. He heads downstairs towards the kitchen. Little Russ shrugs and trots down the stairs and outside the house,

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHNSON BACKYARD, MORNING
dialogues.text: In the yard, while the twins continue to pitch their tent Little Russ, clad in a sweatsuit, begins to pump iron. Ron soon grows bored with the tent. He sits down on the ground with a thud.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: This is sissy stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Camping in the yard. I want to camp out in the real jungle. With wild animals. Cannibals, Grizzly bears.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Grizzly bears don't live in the jungle.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: They do in my jungle. And they'd eat weiners like you for breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SZALINSKI KITCHEN, MORNING
dialogues.text: This entire backyard tableau (Russ' prowess, in particula f is being watched from the house nextdoor by AMY SZALINS . as she toils at the kitchen stove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen-year-old Amy is a pretty, no-nonsense type. She's tall, wears glasses and feels very out of things because

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . ) her height. To help "hide" her stature, she often wal stoop-shouldered and tends to be self-effacing. At 9 A.M., the Szalinski place is already a madhouse. Amy is trying very hard to prepare breakfast for herself, her dad and her kid brother, six-year-old NICHOLAS. She is having a hard time of it, While scrambling the eggs, whis of her straw-colored hair keep falling in her eyes. Little brother NICK ignores her plight, reading a science fiction novel at the kitchen table. One of the brightest tykes imaginable, Nick is far ahead of his peers in terms of schoolwork, which pleases his parents but annoys Amy, who winds up doing most of the drudge work. Nick is terrified of the real world. He is small and thin and has asthma. When faced with a problem he, more often than not plays "sick."

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: How's the toast coming?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Fine. He glances into the frying pan at what is supposed to be scrambled eggs.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Mom never made them like that.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Mom's not here. NICK (after a beat) When do you think she's coming back?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don't know. Maybe never. Nick stares at the eggs as Amy begins to pour them out on a platter. The eggs resemble something yellow that has ju been hit by a car traveling at a very high speed. He snif at the goop.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I hope she comes back soon, Amy glances at the toast. Smoke is billowing from the toaster,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: i, Nick! The toast is smoking! Do you know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It's hot?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Straight-A student but you can't make toast.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I want to be a scientist like dad, not a cook.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Where is dad?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Upstairs. AMY (sighing) As usual.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, MORNING
dialogues.text: In the attic, WAYNE SZALINSKI is putting the finishing touches on an electromagnetic pulse invention he has constructed. A good-natured, easy-going guy with a PhD in physics, Wayne holds a low-level job for an aerospace company and spends his weekends on his own work. A bit of scatterbrain in terms to day-to-day living, for Wayne, physics is easy..,wearing matched socks is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Wayne putters, the family's feisty little Yorkshire terrier, QUARK, watches, mystified.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: This is it, Quark. A red-letter day. He flicks the switch. The machine begins to hum. The dog backs towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: A common laser device you say? The dog's ears flop up, forming the canine version of a question mark.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Wrong, Quark. It's an amazing electromag netic pulse device. If this honey works correctly, its computer scanners will hone in on a solid, inanimate object, analyze and isolate its molecular structure and, then, reduce the space between its electrons. You know what that means, don't you? io Quark stares, dumbfounded, at his master.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It will actually shrink the object. A boon to the space program. It will decrease the size and weight of payloads sent into space. Quark yawns. Wayne walks over to a couch standing next to wall and removes an apple from a paper bag. Quark barks a springs to life, wagging his tail furiously. Could this b snacktime?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Nifty, huh? He walks over to a large steel plate, the size of a wall, and places the apple on a pedestal.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: The only problem is: I haven't gotten this thing to work yet. But I'm close, Quark. Very, very close. Quark, finally seeing that the apple isn't his, walks bac towards the door, dejected. Wayne puts on protective goggles and activates the double beamed machine. THE TWO BEAMS SPARKLE AND COME TO LIFE,

dialogues.speaker: OF SPARKLING LIGHT SHIMMERS ALONG THE OUTSIDE OF THE APPL
dialogues.text: THE APPLE VIBRATES. Quark cowers. Wayne licks his lips in anticipation, waiting for the apple to shrink.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Come on. Shrink. Shrink.

dialogues.speaker: THERE'S A SUDDEN BLAST. THE WALLS, QUARK AND WAYNE ARE
dialogues.text: COVERED WITH A SMALL SHOWER OF APPLE SAUCE. Quark happily licks the sauce off his paws. Wayne sighs, turns off the machine, picks up his notes an a pencil and flops down on his favorite couch. Wayne sits on it upside down, his sauce-spattered head dangling over the side. He stares into space. He sees Quark's head looming before him, upside down. Qua begins to lick the applesauce off his master's face.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Bummer, Quark. The dog licks.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: On the plus side, we have discovered a very expensive way to make apple sauce.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 7
dialogues.text: The dog finishes his facial snack and trots out of the room. Wayne begins making notes. AMY (0.s.) Dad! Come and get it. Wayne gets up, tucks the pencil behind his right ear and walks out of the room, A beat. He returns to the room and grabs the papers he's left there, placing the pencil down on the couch. He leaves the room again, A beat. He comes back in and picks up his pencil. He exits.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SZALINSKI KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne wanders into the kitchen, making notes. He's diligently studying a haphazardly piled sheaf of papers i his hands, not at all watching where he's going. Amy guid him-so he doesn't collide with either Quark or Nick (this is something of a tradition). Amy watches her dad.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Dog. Wayne instinctively changes the direction of his left foo so aS not to squash Quark.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Nicholas. Waune pivots, still reading his papers, so as not to smac into Nick. He makes a move to sit down,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Sewing kit. Wayne has almost sat down on a small table housing a sewi basket. He lifts his rear at the last minute and slides into the adjoining seat. Nick sighs and begins his morning routine. He pops a seri of pills from prescription bottles and, then, inserts a bronchial ashtma inhaler into his mouth. He takes several Darth Vader-sounding gulps before facing the food, Amy serves what looks like nuked-out bacon and slimed egg to her father as Wayne, elbows on table, continues to pou through his notes.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Elbows up. Wayne lifts his elbows. She slides the breakfast beneath him. He puts down his notes and stares at the food.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Ummm. Looks interesting. What is it?  a

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 8
dialogues.text: AMY (embarrassed) Scrambled eggs. Wayne puts a fork into them, The eggs run through the prongs. He stares at the food. Amy walks quickly towards cabinet drawer,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I'll get you a spoon. Her father reaches for a slice of toast. it's black. He makes a move to butter it. The toast crumbles on impact, shrugs and goes back to his notes, scribbling furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you pick up the refill on Nick's inhaler, dad? WAYNE (still scribbling) Momon.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Dad. You promised, How could you forget? You were picking up my dress from the cleaners next door. Wayne “nmmmm's” ‘and continue to scribble.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You forgot the dress, too? No response.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Dad! I need that dress! There's a school dance Friday night.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nobody's asked you to go.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, someone might!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Mmnonon,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: No wonder Mom left, All you think about is that shrinking machine.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It's not a shrinking machine. It's an amazing electromagnetic pulse device. Wayne continues to scribble. Nick looks at him, expecting compliment. Amy givea Nick a "nyah nyah" glance.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 9
dialogues.text: AMY (muttering) You're so obnoxious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Wayne stops scribbling and jumps up to g it, taking his notes with him. Nick stirs his eggs.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Could I have a straw? Amy snatches his plate away.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Look. If you don't want to eat it, fine. Quark will. She dumps the breakfast into the dog's bowl. Quark sniffs it and backs away, Nick flashes Amy a knowing, smug smile

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne runs for the phone in the hallway, still juggling h papers. He picks up the receiver, glancing at the notes. It's his wife, DIANE.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIANE (v.0.) Wayne? It's Diane. Wayne perks up.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Oh, hi honey. Gee, I'm glad you called. We miss you a lot. How's the new apartment.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DIANE'S APARTMENT, DAY
dialogues.text: Diane, a pretty woman in her mid-to-late thirties, stands ‘in a studio apartment filled with unpacked boxes and crates. It's clear she hasn't settled into her new lifestyle.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Just great. Wonderful. Lovely. I just called to remind you to take your suits to the dry cleaners. WAYNE (v.o0.) Oh, yeah, Right. fo DIANE CD And don't forget the food shopping has to be done today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: } WAYNE (v.o.) Jeeez, Thanks for reminding me. DIANE (smiling) How's the experiment going?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I'm close. Uh, really, really close. DIANE (v.0.) Well, I thought I'd wish you good luck today at the scientific congress.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'll need it. All I have are my theories but, honey, if they go for them, they could fund my work for the next year. It'll be tough without physical proof, though. Scientists are weird, DIANE (v.o.) I never would have guessed. Wayne stands, flustered, at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIANE (v.0.) Wayne? About the divorce.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. The papers are ready? DIANE (v.0.) Uh-huh, WAYNE (visably shaken) I thought it would take a little longer.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Well...you really miss me? WAYNE (v.0.) A lot. One hundred per cent squared. DIANE (smiling) It's funny. You never seemed to notice me when I was around. WAYNE (v.o.). ‘\ I know, honey. I've just been so pre- SI occupied with my work. Why don't you come back home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J INT. HALLWAY, DaY As Diane talks, Wayne finds himself staring at his notes. DIANE (v.0.) Wayne, I miss you. I miss the kids. Bo you think we can ever be a family again? A real family? Silence. Wayne gapes at his notes. DIANE (v.o0.) Wayne? WAYNE (excited) Of course! I know exactly what went wrong! DIANE (enthused, v.o.) Really? What? WAYNE (staring at notes) It should have been x over y, not y over x. The beams didn't meld! They collided!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You haven't heard anything I've said, have you? WAYNE (v.0.) I did. I said I missed you and you said...something back.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, DAY
dialogues.text: She slams the phone down hard. CLICK.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Diane? Diane? He puts down the phone. Amy is standing next to him.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Uh, that was mom. She says ‘hi.' We had a bad connection.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I thought Nick and I would visit her today.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Uh, no need. She's coming over sometime this weekend.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOUSE, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne walks through the house, collecting his hat and coa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: } and stuffing his papers into his briefcase. His kids tr behind him. He tosses on a very loud tie and heads for th front door. He still holds a notepad in his hand. He's studying it as he heads for the door. He reaches for the doorknob and misses. Amy opens the door for him.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Good luck, dad.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hmmomn.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Good luck! Wayne walks out the door. Amy closes it behind him. Amy a Nick sigh and glance at each other. They mouth the words “one, two, three..." There's a knock at the door. It's Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Wish me luck, guys.

dialogues.speaker: AMY/NICK
dialogues.text: Good luck, dad.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I'll only be gone for a few hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne heads for the car. Amy eases the door closed, a wistful expression on her face,

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI HOME, DAY
dialogues.text: Walking towards his car, Wayne encounters Russ and Mae Johnson. Mae is busily tending to her pride and joy: her all-encompassing flowerbeds. Big Russ still wears his cap

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Hey, Szalinski, working on a Saturday?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, Russ, You know how it is.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: I thought maybe you'd fix up your yard today. It's getting to look like a jungle.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Taken care of. I hired the Pervis boy to cut the grass.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Your house could use some sprucing up, too.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 13
dialogues.text: MAE (nudging Russ) Russell. Wayne sighs. He's been through this before.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Tell you what, Russ. If you'd like, I'll hire your company to fix it up. How's that?

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: No way. Olympian Construction doesn't diddle with small jobs. We only tackle The Big Stuff. Wayne shrugs and gets into his car.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe someday I'll get a bigger house. . Mae chuckles at Wayne drives off.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Egghead. I oughtta....

dialogues.speaker: . MAE
dialogues.text: Forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Yeah. He wouldn't expect that. Mae leaves, turning her attention to the flowers on the side of the house. Big Russ looks around. Reaching under his hat, he pulls out a pack of cigarettes. He produces a bent cigarette, sniffs it, straightens it, places it in h mouth and is about to light up when.... : MAE (0.s8.) Russell. You're not thinking of smoking, are you? He removes the cigarette, stashes the pack and calls back sweetly.

dialogues.speaker: _ BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: No, dear. You know I've given that up.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SZALINSKI KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, in the Szalinski kitchen, Nick sits in the window with Quark, where he's constructing a small town made out of Lego (tiny plastic bricks). He takes a whiff his asthma inhaler as Quark begins to growl. Quark spots Johnson's cat, Cicero, in the Johnson yard. The cat is tw as big as the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHNSON BACKYARD, DAY
dialogues.text: In the Johnson backyard, Ron has disappeared momentarily. Don sits in the tent, gazing into the fierce "jungle” through binoculars. Their pet cat, Cicero, walks up and stares into them. Don blinks and looks up. Little Russ continues to work out. Ron reappears, walking over to Don Cicero pays no mind.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Wanna have some real fun?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You're not going to try to shave Cicero again, are you? The cat tenses.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No, better than that. Come on. Ron is hiding something behind his back. He takes Don to the fence seperating the two yards and produces a bottle syrup.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Watch this.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Does mom know you have that? Ron doesn't answer. He pours a healthy wad of syrup on th fence. Flies begin to. land on it. They get trapped in it Ron is delighted. RON (to flies) Gotcha.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What's so exciting about this?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: The real fun comes when we feed them to spiders.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Gross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, they're only bugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Russ walks, disgruntled, into the yard. He spots the twins, frowns, and walks towards them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a . Nu DON ~— Here comes dad. He looks mad,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Dad's always mad. Even when he's happy. Ron, thinking fast, ditches the syrup. It lands in the Szalinski yard nextdoor, where the bottle empties onto a patch of grass.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: What are you two up to?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Nothing, dad. We're just watching bugs. Right, Don?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Well, don't watch the bugs in the Szalinski yard. Watch your own bugs. Big Russ walks over towards Little Russ as Mae enters the yard to tend to some of the flowers back there. Don turns - to Ron and points to the syrup.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Mom's going to miss that syrup.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. Right. Like she takes inventory of the refrigerator every day. DON (shrugging) Wanna play ball?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Only if I bat. Big Russ approaches Little Russ as the boy works out.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Better get a move on, son. You're going to be late for football practice.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Uh...dad.... The boy sits up and faces his father.

dialogues.speaker: C3 BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Se You got to get out there early to get the edge on the other guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sae

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES
dialogues.text: 16 LITTLE RUSS (awkwardly) Dad. I'm not on the team anymore, I was cut.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: «eel know coach Farrell always wants his players there on ti...what?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS -
dialogues.text: I was cut. I was too short and too light.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Who said so?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Coach Farrell.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Oh he did, did he? Well, Bernie Farrell and I go back a long time. We played together. I used to knock him on his keister regularly. Little Russ sighs.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Who the hell does he think he is? I'll get him on the phone, Make him realize how impor- tant being on that team is to you!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: You don't have to, dad. It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: It's not okay. You're the son of Big Russ Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Dad, please. Big Russ leaves the yard. Mae sidles over to Little Russ smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: You told him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't take it too well.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll cool him down. She fixes a stern look on her face and marches towards th backdoor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cy Little Russ stares down at the weights. He sighs and g ~ up at the sky, defeated. He glances into the next yard. tossing a frisbee with Quark. He smiles at her. She looks away. Russ sighs and returns to pumping iron. The twins are now playing ball. Don pitches a ball to Ron who proceeds to swat the ball high into the air. His "hom runs" wind up missing Little Russ by inches. The ball whizzes by Cicero. The cat screeches. Little Russ doens't even have to look up to realize who's doing the damage.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Knock it off, Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: But I'm Don.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: You're going to be dead meat in a minute. Ron continues to swat the ball. Nick, interested, calls t them from the kitchen window.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Better watch out. You might hit that bee~hive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a hive in a tree that straddles both yards. Ron isn't impressed.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What do you know about baseball, baby- brain? You can't play. Ron swings at the next pitch and connects. The ball misse the bee-hive by inches, rebounding off the tree and bouncing back down into the yard. Don flashes his brother smug smile. Ron gulps. He faces Nick.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Lucky guess. For his next turn at bat, however, he changes the angle o his batting position, Nick, not wanting to take any chances, pulls the screen down on the window, knocking a few legos off the windowsill and into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Bees can kill you. If you're allergic. I'm allergic. I could die if I got stung. D Good! Ron takes a fast swing and sends the pitch sailing over t

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 18
dialogues.text: fence seperating the two yards. The ball seems to take forever to reach its target...it smashes through the Szalinski's attic window. There is a terrifyingly long second of silence. All the kids exchange petrified glances.

dialogues.speaker: DON/RON
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Little Russ leaps to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: What have you two done this time? The twins point to each other simultaneously.

dialogues.speaker: DON/RON
dialogues.text: He did it.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Great. You busted the egghead's window. Nick trots out of the house, horrified. Amy runs over to the fence and yells at all three boys.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Can't you kids be careful? Look what you've done, My dad is going to kill me when he comes home. And I'm going to tell them who did it, too.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: They're sorry...aren't you.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You're the one who hit it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You threw it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SZALINSKI ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: In the attic, we see the ball perched precariously on a ledge directly above the machine's innerworkings. It is slowly teetering on the edge. It rolls off and smashes in the intricate, computer chip-laden guts of the machine, nestling in front of the power source of one of the two particle beam "cannons." The gizmo sputters to life. A complicated computer, reple with screen, is hooked up to what looks like two laser

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "cannons." The computer, which analyzes anything placed before the particle beams, goes haywire. The two gun-like devices begin jerking back and forth and up and down, Only one of the barrels functions, however,

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SZALINSKI YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: In the backyard, Russ calms Amy down.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We'll get the window fixed. We'll pay for it out of the twins' allowance.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: But I didn't do anything.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. If anyone should pay for it, it should be baby-brain. He made me move.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I heard what Nick told you. You would have gotten stung by those bees and died if it wasn't for Nick.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: My hero.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Actually, very few people die from bee stings. Unless, you're allergic. I'm allergic. Ron snorts derisively. Amy shoots Nick a dirty look. She hates it when Nick acts smart. Which is almost all the time. DON (to Amy) Can we at least have our ball back? RON (laying it on thick) Puleeeeze?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, all right. Nick? Take them upstairs and give: them their ball.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Come on.  ©

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 20
dialogues.text: Nick leads the twins into the house. AMy and Little Russ are left standing awkwardly in the yard. Amy is several inches taller. She tries to slouch.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I'm really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You should be.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. (beat) I saw you throwing the frisbee to the dog. You're pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Ummmm. Ever play with people?

dialogues.speaker: INT, ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: Nick takes the twins.into the attic to retrieve the ball. The machine, at present, seems harmless enough. Only WE S THE COMPUTER SCREEN TRACKING THE CHILDREN'S MOVEMENTS, Do and Ron are amazed at the gizmo.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Wow! Look at this stuff. It's right out of Star Trek.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It's my dad's, He works for an aerospace company. DON (looking for the ball) Your dad's a mad scientist?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No. He's pretty calm.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Just look for the ball, okay? Ron walks offscreen. The kids look for the ball. While th search, THE WORKING LASER CANNON BEGINS TRACKING RON'S MOVEMENTS, AIDED BY THE COMPUTER. No one notices. Don loo at Nick. Nick is standing, facing the wall, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don't know. Something's different.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 21
dialogues.text: Don steps on something. It crunches. Curious, Don bends towards the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Hey, Ron. Look at this neat stuff, He gets down on all fours and stares at the floor. The attic furniture is there, 1/4 inch tall.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It looks like the prizes you get in Crackerjack boxes, only better.

dialogues.speaker: WE HEAR A LOUD "POP." A FLASH OF LIGHT BURSTS FROM
dialogues.text: OFFSCREEN. Don turns around.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Ron? Ron? Don't play around.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey! All my mom's stuff is gone! Nick turns around in time to see THE STACATTO BEAMS CONNE

dialogues.speaker: ON DON. DON IS IMMEDIATELY SHRUNK, THE ENERGY OF THE PROC
dialogues.text: CAUSING A RESOUNDING BANG AND A FLASH OF LIGHT. Nick is tossed onto the floor. He crawls to where Don has stood. stares at the floor. Both Ron and Don are there, as teeny weeny as can be.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It works! The machine begins to aim its laser cannon on Nick. Nick' elation fizzles.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It works? He makes a move for the door. BZAAAP. THE BEAM SMASHES IN

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Both Amy and Russ grow restless.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I'm going upstairs. Those brothers of yours better not be teasing Nick. You may not be able to control them, but I can. She turns to go inside, putting her hand on the railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 22
dialogues.text: pulls her hand back, terrified.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Waaargegeh!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: What is it? What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: A bug. A bug. I hate bugs. It touched me. Little Russ takes his finger and "pings" the unseen bug o the stoop. It lands on the ground. He takes his foot and squashes it.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Better? AMY (sooo mature) Hmph. Murderer. She storms inside. Russ is left in the yard. Quark walks to him, wagging his tail.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: You're lucky you're a dog.

dialogues.speaker: INT, ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: Amy enters the attic. AMY . . Nick? BZZZAAAP. AMY IS SHRUNK. She finds herself on the vast floor of the attic, together with the three other childre The foursome find themselves 1/4 inch tall, stranded on a vast wooden plain. Shrunken furniture is everywhere. The twins aren't at all pleased.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I don't know how you did it, but you did it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything. It was that machine,

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You must have touched it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You were the one who liked it. I thought it was junk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up! Both of you! Nick? She walks over to her brother, who is mesmerized by the towering machine.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What happened? Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We haven't gone anywhere, We're : still here. We've been shrunk, that's all.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: That's all?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Little Russ sits next to Quark when a tall, gangly kid enters the yard. It's TOMMY PERVIS, munching on an ever- present bag of oreos.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Hey, Russ. Mr. Szalinski around?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Naaah.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: If you see him, tell him I'll be.a little late mowing his lawn. I gotta go shopping with my mom, She wants me to get new shoes. He points to his jogging shoes. They're falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Stupid, huh? These are just getting good. Russ smiles at Tommy exits.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: Catch you later.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Yeah, Later, Pervis. Russ sits in the yard a beat. He then gets up and stands under the attic window.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Hey, you guys! Come on down! No answer. He walks up to the back door and slowly swings it open,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don? Ron? He enters the house. Quark is left outside, whining.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: Russ slowly enters the attic.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Guys? Nothing seems amiss. The shrunken kids, on the floor, spo Little Russ, now an Olympian giant.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Look out!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Go back!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Go get help! Get my dad! Russ doesn't hear the teeny-weenies, let alone see them. glances suspiciously around the attick. Hearing a strange buzzing sound, he turns around in time to see the LASER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time his titanic feet hit the attic floor, the teen weenie kids are tossed up and down into the air, the vict of a boy-made earthquake. They try to struggle to their feet and stay upright but it's a losing battle. Every tim they stand up, they’re thrown to the ground again. Little Russ moves towards them. One of his giant feet smashes the trunk to a pulp. The kids scurry about, tryin to stay out of the way of Russ' tennis shoes. Don slips down into a crack between two floor boards as o of the shoes hurties down towards the floor. Ron hits the deck as the shoe comes down atop him. He's so small, however, that he fits inbetween one of the grooves on the shoes' sole. The shoe returns skyward, leaving Ron unhurt Russ continues his wild dance AS THE BEAMS SKITTER BY HIM

dialogues.speaker: \ CONNECT. BZZZAAAP. POW
dialogues.text: at Russ is now insect-sized, too. He lies on the floor, moaning, totally in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, the baseball, still balanced on the machinery, tumbles off the invention and onto the floor. It rolls, poulder-sized, towards the kids. They scatter. Amy stands frozen in her tracks, as the ball heads directly for her.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Amy! Russ sees what's going on and gets to his feet. In the be of football styles, he tackles the frightened girl. They both go tumbling out of the way of the titanic ball. The ball barrels into the rest of the tiny pieces of furnitur flattening most of them, Amy and Russ stare at each other as the twins and Nick run up to them. Russ helps Amy to h feet.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you. Without the baseball putting pressure on its inner- workings, the machine hisses to a halt and shuts down, The kids stand, confused, on the vast attic floor. The reality of the situation hits them at once. Amy turns angrily towards Russ.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Why didn't you go for help?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: How was I to know what was going on up here?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You could have looked for us.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, then, you should have moved faster. Ducked the beams. She stands, looking down at him. He raises himself on his toes.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Like you got out of the way of the ball, right? What do we do now?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I guess we just wait until dad gets home. He'll know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: If he doesn't...he'll step on us. That remark visably shakes Ron.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What????

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Don't worry. RON (recovering) Who's worried? I'm...bored.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALL, DAY
dialogues.text: At the science convention, Wayne's theories are greeted b the seriousness usually reserved for Henny Youngman routines. He's in front of an equation-laden blackboard, holding his papers in his hand. One young, arrogant scientist, FREDERICKSON, is particularly hard on Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICKSON
dialogues.text: What you're trying to say is that size is relative, eh, mister Szalinski? WAYNE (annoyed) Yes, I am, Professor Frederickson.

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICKSON
dialogues.text: That's the most idiotic thing I've ever heard, Size is definitive. What's big is big. What's small is small. The crowd seems to agree with Frederickson.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You're wrong!

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICKSON
dialogues.text: Where's your proof? You have no proof! Wayne is stuck and he knows it.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: When Einstein came up with theories that led to the Atomic Bomb, you didn't ask him to blow one up, did you?

dialogues.speaker: FREDERICKSON
dialogues.text: You, Mr. Szalinski, are no Einstein. The crowd laughs. Frederickson, sneering, gets up and wal out. The rest of the scientists follow, leaving Wayne alo at the podium, An older scientist, DR. BRAINARD, walks up

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 27
dialogues.text: to Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Dr. Brainard.

dialogues.speaker: BRAINARD
dialogues.text: Don't take it so hard, Wayne, Your ideas are very innovative. It will take time to convince people, Even I've had my share of problems with committees. Wayne puts his notes in his briefcase, WAYNE (sadly) They even laughed at my tie. Brainard stares at Wayne's loud tie.

dialogues.speaker: BRAINARD
dialogues.text: Don't feel badly. Anyone would laugh at that tie.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI HOUSE, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne's car pulls up in front of his home. Wayne walks up towards the house, crestfallen.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark runs up to greet him, barking. WAYNE (softly) Hiya, Quark. Okay. Treats. I know.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne walks into the kitchen and gives Quark a milkbone. The dirty dishes are still in the sink, Wayne makes a mental note of that and calls out into the back yard.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Amy? Nick?

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: Upstairs, the kids perk up.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It's Dad! The kids begin yelling.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Up here!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We're up here!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Mr. Szalinski!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yo!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne walks through the house.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Kids? I'm home. Amy? Nick?

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: No reply. Wayne shrugs. He takes off his loud tie, looks it, frowns and places it in the garbage can in the kitche one of the foot-pedal models with a plastic bag liner. It filled with Amy's sorta-scrambled eggs. Glumly, Wayne walks upstairs towards the attic.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: He steps inside and sees the broken glass from the window

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Great. Just great. The kids are screaming to get his attention.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Dad! We're down here!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Mr. Szalinskil!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Egghead! Don punches Ron on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Uh, Mr. Szalinski! Wayne sees that glass fragments are scattered on the top his machine. That doesn't exactly make his day.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: What else can go wrong? He backs over to where his old, reliable couch once stood and sits down, There's no couch. He goes crashing down on the floor. The force of the impact sends the teeny-weenie tumbling onto the ground, Wayne scrambles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Oh, jeez. Not my couch! That's it! That does it! I've had it! I've had it with everything! He storms out of the room. The Kids squeak in protest.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Dad! Come back! “NICK He can't hear you.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I thought your dad was going to save us.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He was upset.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, he had every right to be. These... twirps smashed his machine with their baseball.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Who are you calling a twirp, beanpole?

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY, DAY
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Wayne dials the phone. DIANE (v.0.) This is Diane Szalinski. I'm not home right now, but if you leave a message after the beep, I'll get back to you as soon as I can. WAYNE (outraged) This is Wayne Szalinski. Your husband. I don't mind you taking your stuff out of the house when I'm not home. But our couch? My fost thinking couch? cont.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (3 WAYNE (cont.) " And where are the kids? I'd appreciate it if you return them when you're done with them!!! He slams the phone down. Quark is sitting at the foot of the stairs leading up to the attic, whining.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Nobody likes a whiner, Quark. The dog continues to whine. Wayne sighs, bends down and pets the dog.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Except me,

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: The ground beneath the kids begin to shimmy. Footsteps rumble ominously in the background. Nick jumps excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It's Dad! He's come back! Amy. stares at something high above her as a shadow falls over them all.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, not Wayne has returned with the kitchen trashcan, a broom and dustpan. The kids cling to each other as Wayne begins sweeping up the shards of broken glass. Dust swirls everywhere around the kids as Wayne sweeps around the machine. Finished, he then turns to where the kids are huddled.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Scatter. The children attempt to run. It's no use. They are caught by the broom. The kids attempt to cling to the frayed strands at the edge of the broom. No luck. They are swept into the dustpan. Wayne carries the dustpan over to the open garbage can. In the dustpan, the kids are screaming.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Dad, please!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ne  —_

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Don't!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Mr. Szalinski! It's us!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Knock it off!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Stop! The CAMERA follows the kids as THEY GO TUMBLING THROUGH SPACE TOWARDS THE TRASH.

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRASHCAN, DAY
dialogues.text: They hit wads of junk and go sliding about. Suddenly. DARKNESS.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne has closed the lid on the trashcan. He carries it downstairs,

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark whines madly at Wayne's feet. Wayne tries to ignore the dog. He lifts the bag out of the trashcan, ties the t with a small green wire and makes a move to go into the backyard to place the trash at the rear of the property. Quark barks and tries to follow.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Quark. This isn't for you. It's garbage. You've had your treats. He slams the door in the dog's face. ©

dialogues.speaker: EXT, SZALINSKI BACKYARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne walks to the back of the yard. He places the bag do near the rear fence, next to several other garbage bags. then returns to the house.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark whines and barks. Wayne sits down, dejected, at the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Quark! Not now, okay? The dog, seeing that Wayne is in no mood for audio delights, slinks off into his corner and lies, pensively,

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 32
dialogues.text: in his dog bed, glancing at the door leading outside.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI BACKYARD, DAY
dialogues.text: In the yard, the garbage bag leans against the rear fence

dialogues.speaker: INT. TRASHBAG, DAY
dialogues.text: Inside, in almost total darkness, the kids pull themselve through fast mounds of garbage and stand on an amazingly straight surface. They huddle together, scared and silent. Ron and Don scrape some of the slimed eggs off their shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeechhhh.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What is this junk? More of your dad's experiments?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: They're eggs.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Peeee-yoooo. Silence. The kids gaze glumly into the darkness. Nick speaks. Slowly. Quietly.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Unless we get out of here, we're going to be taken to the dump in two days. Amy and Russ exchange somber glances. Don reaches into hi pocket. He nudges his brother. Ron suddenly grins and reaches into his pocket. Both boys produce pen knives.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Lion scouts to the rescue! Both boys tear into the thick side of the bag. The kids gather behind them.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Quit shoving.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: We're not. The children, perched on garbage tilted on an angle, are leaning on the twins. As the twins cut further, the garba shifts more, The twins finally rip a hole in the bag. The angle of the garbage causes the children to tumble out of the sack. A fistful of garbage slides out along with them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh-oh.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SZALINSKI BACKYARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids and the garbage land in the yard below with a SPLAT. The kids stumble to their feet, making disgusted faces while scraping the bits of egg and bacon off them. RON (proudly) Nothing to it. He ceremoniously slides his knife back into his pocket. A the kids stop what they're doing and gape at what lies ahead. They are confronted by a world unlike anything they've ever seen. From their quarter-inch height, the backyard is a totally alien landscape: large, green, never-ending...dangerous,. Before them likes a redwood forest-sized sea of grass, shadow-leaden and forboding with only a stray ray of sunlight or two illuminating the ground, The children sta somberly into the dark forestland. The Johnson kids stand together. Nick stands at Amy's side. Amy begins thinking outloud,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Our only hope is to get back to the house. . If dad's machine can shrink us, it can enlarge us, too. Right, Nick? Nick gapes at the never-ending terrain stretching out bef him. He is stunned. - NICK (softly) I suppose he could reverse the process.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Good. Then all we have to do is get across the yard. Nick stares at the yard. He begins to cough. He pulls out his inhaler and takes several gulps. LITTLE RUSS (to Amy) What's his problem? AMY (softly) Asthma, Nick continues to wheeze. AMY (to Russ) ( ‘ Look. Maybe you and your brothers had better go back to the house on your own. I don't know if Nick can make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: rN : LITTLE RUSS Lf That doesn't sound very....

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: The beanpole's right. The whimpoid will just slow us down.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Can it, motormouth. Ron turns to Don.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I hate girls who're bigger than me. Amy turns to Russ.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You can come back for us later. Nick overhears and turns on Amy angrily.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I can make it.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You know how you get when you're outside too long. You can't breathe.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I can do it. The kids gaze deep into the Bobdingnagian forest.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Okay. So the plan is to get back to the house, right? KIDS (in unison) Right. They stand there a moment longer, looking at each other.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Which way?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: ‘ Straight ahead, I guess. The kids wander deeper into the underbrush, There is very little light. They can't see the sky. They can hear noise - all around them. Buzzing. Crackling. Chomping. Suddenly aaa Ron gives out with a Tarzan yell. The kids almost dro ( > from heart attacks.

dialogues.speaker: CY LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: 7 Knock it off.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hey, this is an adventure, right?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Give me a break.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don't pick on me. You're not even sure we're going the right way. LITTLE RUSS (to Amy) Hmm. He has a point. ‘EXT, FOREST/YARD, DAY He shinnies up a blade of grass. At the top, he stares in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI HOUSE, DAY
dialogues.text: There, looming like a monolithic presence, surrounded by the swirling fog of debris, is the Szalinski fo house...seemingly a hundred miles away. From Russ’ van o point, it looks like Mt. Hood viewed from a great dista

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids cluster around the base of the grass blade.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Can you see the house?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Sure can. Nick breathes a sigh of relief and begins to cough. He takes his asthma inhaler out and gives himself a Darth Vader shot as Russ shinnies down the grass,

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We can probably get there by sundown, Follow me.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. You don't know your way around this yard. You could walk us into a ditch. LITTLE RUSS (patiently) I'm the oldest, okay? oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Co AMY You are not. Besides, I'm the biggest.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: But you're a girl. Nick clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You're both the oldest. Why don't you both take charge? Amy and Russ eye each other cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Sounds good. AMY (reluctantly) Well, okay. Amy and Russ walk off. The three other boys fall in behin

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD,. DAY
dialogues.text: Amy and Russ are in the lead. Amy gazes in awe at the titanic landscape.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You forget just how big this world can be sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: When you're short, you think about that a lot. Amy decides to let that one pass.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Do you really think we can make it back to the house today?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I don't know. It looked pretty far. I didn't want to scare the kids, though. Look. I know we're not friends or anything, but we have to act like we know what we're doing. If the little kids get discouraged, they'll punk out on us. AMY (smiling) . I'll be the mommy and you be the daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not fooling around.

dialogues.speaker: TEENY-WEENIES 37
dialogues.text: AMY (sullenly) I know.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Don glances over his shoulder. He sees something and cock his head. He nudges Nick. Nick turns as well. In the distance, the grass is blowing wildly. First, in one direction, Then, in another. A few pieces of twigs FALL U INTO THE AIR.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Pretty weird.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Look! A mammoth dandelion suddenly LAUNCHES ITSELF INTO SPACE, Nick and Don exchange fishy looks. They turn back to the others. Before they can speak, the SOUND OF PROLONGED THUNDER RIPS THROUGH THE FOREST. There appears to be a re storm brewing. Blasts of wind howl through the oversized blades of grass. Russ is getting uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We'd better get moving. THE EARTH BEGINS TO SHAKE VIOLENTLY BENEATH THE KIDS. The are tossed this way and that. They manage to get back ont their feet by clinging to the tree-sized roots of the gra and weeds. The whole world seems.to be in turmoil. Squail of wind and dust fly everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Earthquake! Nick squints into the grit, wheezing.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Worse! Lawnmower! The kids gape at the approaching cause of the maelstrom.

dialogues.speaker: FOREST FLOOR LIKE AN AVALANCHE OF UPROOTED TREES.
dialogues.text: The kids scramble to their feet and try to outrun the machine, It's no use. Large, boulder-sized pieces of gras are smashing onto the ground all around them.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Get down! Get down!

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 38
dialogues.text: Standing, Russ tries to get all the children flat onto th ground. A blast of wind sends him flying through space so ten feet.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Russell!!!! The terrified children cling to the ground, Russ slowly crawis back towards them. The children huddle together as

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Hold on tight! Above them, THE CIRCULAR BOTTOM OF THE MOWER HOVERS, LIKE

dialogues.speaker: WHIRL MADLY. THE SUCTION CAUSES THE GRASS AROUND THE
dialogues.text: CHILDREN TO UPROOT AND BLAST OFF TOWARDS THE BLADES. The kids cling to each other, Their feet begin lifting from t ground, being drawn to the mower by its tremendous suctio Russ tries to pull the small children down to the ground, They are slowly being lifted.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Grab hands! Grab hands! The kids form a human wheel, like earthbound skydivers in formation. They anchor each other as.THE MOWER PASSES DIRECTLY OVER THEM. Don holds onto one of Amy's hands and one of Russ's. He lets out a brief, terrified shriek as A HUGE BLAST OF

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don! Ron stares, horrified, at the sight of HIS BROTHER,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o> LIKE A MADDENED DINOSAUR. A LARGE, BRAND NEW SNEAKER Nd SMASHES DOWN ONTO THE GROUND WITH A CRASH NEAR THEM, The kids are buffeted about. Gradually, the noise subside THE MOWER MOVES ON. The THUNDER of the footsteps fades away. The kids climb out from beneath a blanket of shredded grass, slabs of green about the size of surfboards. Ron i the first one to run off,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don! Don! The other children follow him,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: He's in here somewhere, He has to be. The children begin searching beneath the shards of grass for the missing boy. They can't find him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don! r AMY ~ Donald!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don? Don't kid around. Come on out. The kids continue to search beneath the grass. Nick begin panting. He's tearing into the grass with all his might. After a tense minute or so, the children stop their searc Ron gapes at the shredded grass.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don...mowed down at the age of ten. DON (0o.s.) Hey! Over here! Whoah.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids turn as one and see that, a city block away, Don is appearing and disappearing over a small forest of gras He is literally bouncing up and down out of view. The kid run forward, The children run forward and enter.... f EXT. FLOWERBED/YARD, DAY

dialogues.speaker: CU
dialogues.text: The children run into what appears to be a giant forest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: \ filled with flowers; actually, it's just a few feet of i mee overgrown wild flowerbed sitting in the yard, Don i bouncing up and down on a flower, using it like a | trampoline. Unfortunately, he has no control of his bou

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You jerk! You'll do anything for attention!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Whoaaaaahhh,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don't mess around, Don.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything. Ron makes a move to grab his brother off the flower, He keeps on missing him. On the fifth or sixth bounce, Don winds up tumbling onto the ground. He gets up to his feet He's shakey and there's a lopside grin on his face. : Everyone hugs Don except Ron. When the other kids are d ‘ Don stands, smiling at his brother. He hugs Ron. Ron ) brushes him aside. :

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You're a real turkey, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GIANT FLOWERBED, DAY
dialogues.text: Amy and Russ, with the knowledge that Don is safe, take i the flowerbed. They stare, transfixed, at the Olympian sw of color. f AMY : It's beautiful. Russ stares at Amy. She faces him, beaming. Slightly embarrassed, he looks away.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: : Yeah. It's okay. Ron checks out the flowers, unimpressed. He gets an idea. nudges Don. The twins grin at the flowers. Ron turns to D They smile in unison,

dialogues.speaker: RON/DON
dialogues.text: . Recess! . They run by Nick towards the flowers. Nick, caught in t ( ) wake, goes spinning. He lands on the ground in. sitti Ned position. For one, brief moment, the kids act like to children. It's as if they've stumbled onto paradise. Amy

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 41
dialogues.text: and Russ stand behind Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It looks like Oz. The twins discover that the shorter flowers make perfect trampolines, They begin bouncing up and down and from one flower to another. Ron gives another Tarzan yell.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Up, up and awaaay!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Be careful. You might hurt yourselves. He catches himself.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I can't believe I said that. He turns and sees that Amy has fashioned a hula skirt around her belt from large flower pedals.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, honey. I just have to have this dress. LITTLE RUSS (grinning) Cut it out, willya?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Please, dear. We can charge it, Nick giggles. The twins leap by a "puff" flower. The flow disintegrates and rains down a shower of flowery "snow." The clearing really begins looking like a fairyland, now. Nick gets up and starts wheeling joyfully through the "snow." Soon, he begins to sneeze. He pulls out his asthm inhaler and takes a whiff.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. It's my hayfever. I'm fine. He smiles. Pockets his inhaler. Puffs out his chest. He marches straight for the flowers, determined to have fun, The twins are whooping and rebounding wildly from flower flower. Nick hesitantly tries a bounce on a nearby flower He lands awkwardly. He tries another bound. An another. H loses his balance and winds up tumbling onto the ground. looks around, embarrassed. Amy and Russ have seen him and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: an

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 42
dialogues.text: laugh. Nick grins, realizing that the laughter isn't malicious. He gets back onto the flower and begins bounci away, gradually getting the hang of it. NICK (almost whispering) Yahooo. Gathering courage, he lets out a full whoop.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yahooooooo!!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear, very faintly, the sounds of the frolicking children, AS WE SOAR HIGH ABOVE THE YARD, A DEAFENING BUZZING SOUND ECHOING IN OUR EARS.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, YARD/FOREST, DAY
dialogues.text: Amy and Russ watch the younger children play. Russ glance at the sun. He calls to the kids on the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Okay. It's time to move on. Nick stops bouncing immediately. Ron and Don continue playing.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Come on, guys.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No way, Jose.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I'm not kidding. I'm counting to five. RON (to Don) He's beginning to sound a lot like dad.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Scary, huh?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Ronald. Donald. AMY (to Russ) Try to control those two, will you? Ron notices Nick's hesitation. The little boy is obviousl waiting for a cue from the twins.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What are you stopping for? We're having fun, right? Nick nods,

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: But Russ said... RON (mimicking) "But Russ said." What a wuss. Russ walks forward and snatches Don off a flower. Don quietly stands by his side. Russ then pulls Ron off a flower. Ron is struggling.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Hey. Cut it out! You wanna hurt me or something? I'll tell mom! . RUSS (quietly) Look. There's something you'd both better understand. We're in a lot of trouble, okay? This isn't a game. We could die out here and no one would notice. The only way we're going to get out of this is if we all help each other. Got that?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Uh-huh, Little Russ, thinking it's all settled, turns his back on the twins. Ron immediately runs back to a flower and launches himself, again, on a flower-trampoline. RON. But first....playtime. The twins start bouncing again, Nick laughs and resumes a well, Amy and Russ exchange exasperated glances.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Amy and Russ watch the younger children play. Amy stiffen She hears a faint buzzing.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 44
dialogues.text: (oo LITTLE RUSS Se Sounds like a buzzsaw. It's probably my dad. i Amy stares at the sky around her.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It's coming from different directions,

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Naaaah. It's just your ears playing tricks on you. 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you shut up and listen? Russ glowers but does as he's told. The buzzing seems to coming from all around them. Russ is getting nervous. The three younger children gradually slow down their bouncing. Ron, Don and Nick sta on their flowers, heads cocked. The noise around them gro louder and louder. The flower bed sounds like the streets London just before the Nazi Blitz. The droning is overwhelming. Amy screams and points as a dark cloud fall upon the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: s A TITANIC HONEYBEE HOVERS OVER THE FLOWERBED.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Hit the dirt! The twins dive off the flowers and run in one direction. Nick runs in another. Amy and Russ retreat together. THE

dialogues.speaker: STUFFING THE STICKY YELLOW STUFF INTO "BASKETS" ON ITS RE
dialogues.text: ! LEGS. From the children's POV, the bee is the size of a flying VW van. Nick crouches beneath a flower, wheezing. The bee alights directly next to him. The pollen-gathering BEE DESCENDS LOWER AND LOWER. Nick trembles, trying to hold his breath Amy makes a move to yell. Russ puts a hand around her mou

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Shhhhh. Nick watches, horrified, AS THE BEE GETS CLOSER AND CLOSE He's almost hyperventillating. THE BEE SUDDENLY SCOOPS NI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy breaks away from Russ and runs towards the bee,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Nick! a

dialogues.speaker: S
dialogues.text: Ron and Don gape at each other,

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Holy...

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Cow! Nick is half-smothered in pollen,

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Amy! Russ springs forward and, sprinting in front of Amy, leap onto a flower, using it as a trampoline.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Wait here! THE BEE, SATIATED, BEGINS TO TAKE OFF. Russ bounces from flower to flower, finally sailing through the air towards the bee. HE DIVES ONTO THE BACK OF THE RETREATING BEE.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Russell! Help!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy and the twins watch, fearfully, as THE BEE, ALONG WIT NICK AND RUSS, disappears in the sky. The humming noise fades into the distance. The twins stand, transfixed,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Now, what?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: We do as your brother told us. We wait.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SKY, DAY
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, on THE BACK OF THE BEE, RUSS GETS A BREATHTAKI

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Russ! Russ!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Hold on tight, Nick. Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: om WITH ITS SURPRISE BAGGAGE.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Near the house, we see the Pervis boy surveying the newly cut grass.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SKY, DAY
dialogues.text: Russ still struggles for control of the bee, He looks up. THE BEE IS HEADING STRAIGHT FOR THE PERVIS BOY'S HEAD.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Pervis!!!! Look out!!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Heyl!!!

dialogues.speaker: EXT.. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: We hear the tiny voices of the teeny-weenies call out. So does the Pervis boy, sort of. Confused, he starts swattin at the bee,

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY
dialogues.text: G'wan. Getoutta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bee dodges and ducks the boy's swings.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS/NICK
dialogues.text: Woaaaaaaaaahhhhhh! I!!1!!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Amy and the twins linger by the flowerbed.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I don't think we should hang around here,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: We promised we'd wait and we will.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You promised. I say we should go after Russ, You're just yellow.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: If I were your sister, I'd spank you until you couldn't sit down.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: If you were my sister, I'd put myself up for adoption. Let's go. (to Don) I'm going to find Russ and the wuss. Are you coming or what? Ron stalks off. Don sighs, gives Amy a "what can I do?" l and takes off after his brother. Amy hesitates, watching two boys disappear. She grits her teeth and follows then.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SZALINSKI HALL, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne is on the phone. We hear the last part of Diane's message before the beep. He slames the phone down. Quark at his feet, whining.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I know. I know, Lunchtime. The doorbell rings. Wayne walks towards the front door. °

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It's not like Amy and Nick to miss lunch without letting me know. Even if they are with their mother. “INT. SZALINSKI HOUSE, DAY Wayne opens the door. Diane is there. They stare at each other angrily. Diane thrusts a handful of papers in his hand,

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Just sign them and I'll be on my way. She marches inside. Wayne stands at the door. He pokes hi head outside and looks to the left and the right, expecti to see the kids. They aren't there. Puzzled, he returns inside and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Where are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: And the couch? Where's my thinking couch?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Where it alweys is.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It ig not. You took it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I did not.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Yes, you did, You came back this morning and stole it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: For your information, I spent the entire morning working on a deadline. She glances around,

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Where are the kids?

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Diane walks into the kitchen, Wayne is trailing in the hall behind her. Quark continues to whine. Wayne raises a WAYNE. They're with you, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Quiet, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: With the couch? And your things?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Earth to Wayne. Earth to Wayne. I don't have the couch. Where are the children? finger to his lips, thoughtfully, Quark barks.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Quiet, Quark, Well, I did forget to pick up Amy's dress and Nick's aathma medicine.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: How could you?  qo

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You didn't remind me... Quark barks again.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE/WAYNE
dialogues.text: Quiet, Quark!!! Quark stops barking and runs around in front of the back Wayne and Diane walk through the swinging door leading to yard. Quark tries to run out after them. The door swings on him. Thump. The dog retreats back into the kitchen yel

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne stands on the back steps, Diane behind hin.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE/DIANE
dialogues.text: Amy? Nick?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Deep in the forest, the twins and Amy hear a thundering roar. It's the pitch of a tyrannosaurus rex. We can barel make out the words,

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE/DIANE ROAR
dialogues.text: Amy? Nick? The kids run forward.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Mom! Dad!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Mr. Szalinski! We're over here! Over here!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yo! Mr. Szalinski!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHNSON YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, while Wayne and Diane are calling for their kids. Big Russ, still wearing his cap, walks out into his backyard where Mae is watering her garden.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Ron! Don! Russell!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids continue to run forward, the twins take the lead leaving Amy far behind.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: It's dad!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Dad! Over here!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHNSON YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Russ, spotting Wayne, walks over to the fence. He leans h arm on the fence and comes up with an elbow-ful of syrup. He frowns as Wayne walks over.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Hey, Szalinski, The yard looks a lot better. You know, you could probably have a flower garden over there.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Begonias would be nice.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I always meant to...but there never was the time....

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hey, have you seen my kids?

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Naah. I was just looking for mine. They never miss lunch.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Mine, either. Wayne and Russ look at each other for a moment. They both away from each other and, trying their best to ignore eac other, begin calling their children's names. They stop, waiting for each other to continue. A beat. When neither begins calling again, each feels it's okay to continue, T both begin call again in tandem.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JUNGLE/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The children continue to run breathlessly forward, shouti to their parents.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It's no use, They can't hear us.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I thought your dad was a genius,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He is, but he still has normal ears.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The parents stand on either side of the fence, Mae continues to water her garden,

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Nice to see you back, Diane. Welcome home.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I just came to check on the kids... but Wayne seems to have misplaced them,

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I'm sure they'll turn up for supper.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: You're probably right. Good to see you, Mae. Wayne and Diane walk back towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHNSON HOUSE, DAY
dialogues.text: Mae finishes watering her lawn, She turns off the nozzle the house and glances at the Szalinski's backyard. It's a all yellow.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Tsk, Tsk, Poor grass. She turns the nozzle back on and sends a spray of water o the fence and into the yard.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/JUNGLE, DAY
dialogues.text: Russ and Nick slowly sit up, dazed. As they do so, THEY

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Are you strong enough to run?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Y-y-you bet. The boys start to run from the bee. THE BEE SPRINGS FORWA

dialogues.speaker: THE BOYS IN A MATTER OF SECONDS.
dialogues.text: The boys seemed doomed when, WITHOUT WARNING, THE BEE IS K.0.'S BY A TITANIC DROPLET OF WATER. The two boys stop, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Are we safe?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.... Suddenly, TITANIC DROPLETS OF WATER BEGIN FALLING ALL ARO

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Come on! Up here! Russ shinnies up a blade of grass, pulling Nick up behind him, AS THE YARD SLOWLY FILLS WITH WATER.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: We see Mae, humming merrily, hosing down the lawn in earn

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/JUNGLE DAY
dialogues.text: Amy and the twins walk through the twisted terrain.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Nick?

dialogues.speaker: RON/DON
dialogues.text: Russ? A ROARING NOISE sends the ground beneath them trembling.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What the? They turn and see a CASCADING WALL OF WATER HEADING FOR T

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Head for higher ground! The three children run for their lives AS THE WALL OF WAT

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Look! Ahead of them lies a gigantic pop bottle cap. Amy vaults the cap, turns, and yanks the two small boys inside by th belts AS THE WATER CATCHES UP WITH THEM. BEFORE THEY KNOW

dialogues.speaker: RAPIDS RIDE. THE BOTTLE CAP SPINS MADLY AS THE WATER
dialogues.text: RUSHES THROUGH THE YARD. The three children cling to its side as it bumps and zig-zags through the raging river, l a waterborne tilt-a-whirl car.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Russ! Russ bends down and grabs Nick by the back of his shirt j as the little boy begins to fall into the water. Russ grimaces, Nick's struggling body causing him to slide dow the grass blade. The grass blade is being buffeted by the raging river, The two boys are getting closer to the wate when...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Nick! Russellt

dialogues.speaker: THE SODA BOTTLE CAP GOES CAREENING DOWN THE RIVER TOWARDS
dialogues.text: RUSS AND NICK. The twins hold on for dear life as the cap barrels towards the grass blade.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Geronimo!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Mae, quite pleased with his act of kindness, shuts off th hose and leaves the yard.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVERBED, DAY
dialogues.text: The cap goes crashing into a riverbank as the flood water recede. The children tumble, gasping from the cap. They collapse on the "riverbed," exhausted. Amy hugs Nick. The twins kneel next to Russ.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Hey, brother. We missed you.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah. We thought some Queen Bee married you or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: co Nick sits up, laughing. He puts his arm around Russ, f uF the twins.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Naaah. But you should have been on that bee! It was great! And, then, Russ made the bee crash, And it came after us and... Russ staggers to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We can talk later. Now, we've got to head home, Agy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RON
