dialogues.text: Aww, come on, Russ. We're tired. AMY (acting like a mother) Listen to Russell. We're all together again, We have to be strong, We have to get home, We can't dally here.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: - Dally?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: She's right, It's getting late. The three young boys look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I bet it's almost suppertime.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I bet mom made hamburgers. He turns to Nick.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Saturday is hamburger night. The three boys aigh hungrily and look at each other sadly

dialogues.speaker: ' LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Come on, troops, { The five kids begin their trek again, Don and Ron, forc . themselves to act like scouts, begin singing "The Green Grass Grew All Around" as they march, Nick joins in as well. Russ and Amy smile at the trio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The three younger boys suddenly come to a stop. They gaze ahead, a look of wonder and pleasure on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: There, before them, illuminated by an almost religiously inspired stream of sunlight is a titanic oreo cookie. Sog ' from the “rainstorm,” the cookie glistens magically lik cream-filled rainbow.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOREST/YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: ! Ron is profoundly moved, The sunlight caresses the oreo 1 magically,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: ' I think I've died and gone to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Ir's as big as a house,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I'm hungry enough to eat it myself.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Double filling. It has double filling. The kids run forward to the cookie. They reach it and beg tearing out handfuls of white cream filling.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I was born for something like this. Don looks up, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Uh, guys?

dialogues.speaker: TWITCHING OMINOUSLY.
dialogues.text: LITTLE RUSS (looking up) In here! Quck! The children dart behind the cover of grass as A HORDE OF

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 56
dialogues.text: RON (whispering) What pigs!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: That's not fair!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That was our cookie. (to Don) I say we fight them.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Stay down. They might think we're food.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You're kidding me. Ants don't eat people.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We're not normal-sized people. They might think we‘re crumbs or enemy insects or something.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: They're only bugs. I squash them all the time.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You couldn't try that now. Ants can lift over twenty times their weight. That's like us lifting a tractor.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No sh...kidding.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: How do you know all this stuff?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I read a lot-of books.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: You must read 24 hours a day. NICK. (shrugging) I don't have anyone to play with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RON (suddenly grinning) I say it's time for a snack,

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Get serious.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I have a plan. Ron tears off a stiff piece of grass and fashions it into spear. He looks at Don. Don sighs, shakes his head and do the same, .

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I hate it when you have plans.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Ready, brother?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: DROPS THE CRUMB. IT BEGINS TO RUN AFTER THE RETREATING
dialogues.text: a COLONY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the kids run through the soggy terrain toward the twins.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Don't let it get away! It'll bring back the others! DON (to Ron) Nice plan.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Okay. Now it's time for plan number two.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Scouts to the rescue! The rest of the kids run up to Don. At first, they all laugh at the sight of Ron, CLINGING TO THE ANT'S BACK. It great sport.

dialogues.speaker: . DON
dialogues.text: Ride ‘em cowboy. Ne Don JUMPS ONTO THE BACK OF THE ANT AS WELL. THE TWINS LOUDLY AS THE ANT CAREENS AROUND THE CLEARING IN CIRCLES.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Okay. Enough fun. Pull him over. ON THE ANT, RON AND DON EXCHANGE GLANCES.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You heard Russ, Pull him over,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You pull him over. Each one of the twins grab an antennae and try to yank th ant in one direction or the other. It doesn't work. They ‘glance meaningfully at each other before turning towards the rest of the kids.

dialogues.speaker: DON/RON
dialogues.text: We can't pull him over. The kids watch helplessly as the twins’ ANT SKITTERS AROU

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Don't let him gol

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I'm not! I'm not! AMY (disgusted) Boys.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Come on, Nick. Russ and Nick charge the ant and try to grab ahold of it, brahma bull wrestler style. The ant easily out maneuvers them. They dive and miss, hitting the muddy dirt with a thud. Nick is slow to get up. Russ grabs the ant by the neck and is carried along, heels dragging on the ground. He is shaken off and falls at Amy's feet.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Pathetic. Russ glances around, looking for some way to help. He pic up one of the twin's spears. Amy looks at the spear, reaches over and bends it easily. She looks at THE RAMPAGING ANT. The spear isn't going to work. Amy spots the fallen crumb and runs towards it. THE ANT CONTINUES TO REEL AROUND. Amy takes a wad of cook in her hand and walks directly in front of the charging ant. Nick, still sitting dazed in the dirt, is horrified. He is coughing and wheezing.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, Amy! Look out! Amy swallows hard and holds her ground. The ant goes skidding to a stop. The twins go tumbling from its back. The ant slowly approaches Amy, antennae twitching. Amy gazes into the face of the little ant. She crinkles her nose. It's repulsive. The ant calmly walks over and gentl removes the small pliece of crumb from her hand. It munch on it merrily. Little Russ walks up to the ant and slips a grass lariet around its neck. The ant, munching merrily, allows it. The twins are both dizzy. They stagger up to Amy.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: All right, Stretch. Stretch the lion tamer. The kids WATCH THE ANT MUNCH THE CRUMB.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Wow. A bug pig-out.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We can't just leave him here. He might bring back the whole colony.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You know, if he'd let us, we could use him for transportation.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: He moves a lot faster than we do. We could get through the yard in half the time.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Ride him like a horse?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Or an elephant in darkest Africa!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Sort of. He's too small to hold all of us, through.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: But he's not tame or anything. How will we steer him?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I have an idea. cUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HOLDING A STICK WITH AN OREO CRUMB AFFIXED TO THE END. TH
dialogues.text: CRUMB IS DANGLING IN FRONT OF THE ANT'S HEAD. The kids ar singing "And The Green Grass Grew Ail Around" while munching smaller crumbs.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Okay. Hang a left.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Who says that junk food isn't good for you? He turns to Amy.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Where to now, Bwana-ette? AMY (laughing) Home, James.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: The name's Tarzan, Ron gives an impromptu yell. He holds the stick directly in front of the ant. The ant plows forward.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOMES, DUSK
dialogues.text: A patrol car sits outside the two homes. There's an offic interviewing Big Russ and Mae at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOHNSON HOME, DUSK
dialogues.text: At the Johnson's, a cop is furiously taking notes as he interviews the parents. coP Any reason your kids would want to run away?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: No. None at all. The twins were in the yard playing and our oldest boy, Russ, was...Oh, God. You don't think because he was cut from the football team.... Big Russ "shhhhh"s her.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: There's no reason my kids would run away. They're happy kids. No problems. cop Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: What's "uh-huh" supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Russell,

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Well, I don't like the way he said "uh-huh." It didn't sound sincere. coP Did you have an argument with your son this morning, Mr. Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: I don't argue with my kids, mister. I discuss things with them. coP Uh-huh. Did you discuss his getting cut from the team?

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: What are you getting at?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Maybe he felt you were angry with hin. BIG RUSS (steamed) Me? Angry with him? I love those kids! I'm their father. I worship the ground they walk on, dammit. Russ kicks his foot forward. He hits a lawn jockey, sendi its head tumbling into space. THe cop looks at him impassively. coP Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: He's doin' it again!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SZALINSKI HOME, DUSK
dialogues.text: Wayne and Diane show a second cop to the front door. They are hand in hand.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Okay, folks. We'll tell all our patrol cars to be on the lookout for two kids and a couch,

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Beige couch.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Right. We'll check in with you tomorrow. The cop leaves the parents, Wayne makes a move to go inside. Diane, glancing at the Johnson's home, where the first cop is leaving, walks out of the front door.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: In a minute, dear. Wayne goes inside. Diane walks over to the Johnson front porch where Mae watches the patrol car drive off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOMES, DUSK
dialogues.text: Mae looks up at Diane and smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Hi, Diane.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Hello, Mae. Problems?

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: The twins and Russ have run away. Diane cocks her head inquisitively.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: I knew Russ was upset this morning, but to run away? I keep on telling Russell, go easy with the children. Don't get so excited, But Russell is just as much a child as the kids are. DIANE (smiling sadly) ( 4 Wayne, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: t i)

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Well, for better or for worse, right? DIANE (awkwardly) Right.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SZALINSKI KITCHEN, DUSK
dialogues.text: Wayne is tethering a barking Quark to a long leash in the kitchen as Diane enters.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Not now, Quark, Did you know the Johnson children are gone, too?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: No. I can't figure why they would have taken the furniture...I wonder if they were upset about breaking the window?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What window?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: In the attic. They threw a baseball through the window and hit my machine and...

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Amy and Nick don't play baseball.... Their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: The Johnson kids do.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE/WAYNE
dialogues.text: They're missing, too. They trot upstairs to the attic.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DUSK
dialogues.text: Wayne picks up the ball. He tosses it to Diane. She looks at it. It has a burn mark on it.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: It has to belong to the twins next door. Wayne inspects the machine.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: The override circuitry is damaged.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: co™ Wayne is onto something. He gets down on his knees.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It's possible that the ball activated the particle beams.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? He crawls around the floor in an exaggerated, careful manner...as if his arms and legs were made of rubber.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I hope...Don't move! Oh, jeez. He gingerly picks up a teen-weeny piece of debris. He hol in the palm of his hand. He looks at the machine. At firs is elated. Then, the reality of the situation hits him. WAYNE (enthused) It works! Then, soberly.

dialogues.speaker: . WAYNE
dialogues.text: \ My god. It works. He stands and, like an Indian rubber man trying to levita off the ground, carefully walks over to Diane on his tip-

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What is it? In his hand is a tiny, perfectly intact, beige couch. It' smaller than a button. WAYNE (somberly) The thinking couch. Diane stares at him, dumbfounded,

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Do you think the kids....?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: If the couch was affected and the kids were up here...all of them... They both get down on their hands and knees,

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Kids? Are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin crawling, trying as hard as possible not to  co

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES . 65
dialogues.text: touch the floor, across the room. They sort of look like Marcel Marceau impersonating a tarantula.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Kids? Careful now. Watch you knees.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I know. I know. Amy? Nick? After a moment of creepy-crawling, Wayne focuses on the dustpan leaning against the wall. He leaps to his feet. Diane gasps.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Get the flashlight! I'll get a magnifying glass! He runs out of the room. Diane follows him, taking veeerr long, bouyant steps.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STAIRWAY, DUSK
dialogues.text: They run downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What about the children?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I swept the room this afternoon and put the trash out in the yard!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DUSK
dialogues.text: In the gathering darkness of early evening, Diane and Way carefully go through the trash, using a large flashlight, the magnifying glass and tweezers. Big Russ Johnson sneaks out into his backyard and leans against the fence. He reaches under his hat and produces cigarette. He lights up and takes a deep breath. He then notices Wayne and Diane. They don't spot Big Russ, howeve He sees the neighbors whispering into the large trashbags as they tweeze their way through the gunk.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Amy? Nick?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Can you hear us? Big Russ gapes at them, straining his ears to hear what they're saying. He can't hear a word. Wayne spots a hole in the side of the bag. He shines the flashlight on it.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Look. The kids must have made it from the inside, see? He trains the flashlight on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Do you think they got out?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: They must have made it into the grass and... He stops mid-sentence, a terrified look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Wayne? What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: The Pervis boy mowed the lawn today! Russ still strains his ears to hear. No dice. Wayne points to several Hefty bags in the corner of the yard.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Let's try those. Wayne and Diane undo the bags and begin sifting through t grass collected in them.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Any?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Nick? Big Russ takes a deep puff.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Eggheads. They're the first to crack under pressure.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, DUSK
dialogues.text: The kids continue to slog onward through the soggy yard. The ant is growing weary. Ron removes the crumb from in front of the ant.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I think the antmobile needs to recharge his batteries. The kids tumble from the sled, They tether the ant and th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o™ . , antmobile to a sta of grass. ( bil 1k of

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It's getting dark.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: We'll never get back in time. Ron seems really depressed. Amy puts an arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: That's okay. At least our dad'1ll know something is wrong if we're not back by supper. He'll look for us.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I don't think he'll see us.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: He doesn't even know we're shrunk. The kids are now sitting, despairing. Amy refuses to be beaten. Oo AMY He'll find us. I know he will.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: She's pretty gutsy.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: For a girl.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: We see that the kids are sitting near the fence, Big Russ above, is still smoking, watching Wayne and Diane in the back of the yard. He casually flicks the ashes off his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the air is filled with a hissing sound.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Look out!

dialogues.speaker: CU LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Take cover!

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 68
dialogues.text: The kids run off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Big Russ continues to flick his ashes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: The kids huddle together, THE ASHES ARE RAINING DOWN

dialogues.speaker: HEAVIER, NOW,
dialogues.text: Ron and Don are huddled under one leaf when a WAD OF ASH ONTOP OF IT, BURNING A HOLE THROUGH IT. Don takes off scr left. Ron runs to screen right, the CAMERA following him. He runs blindly into the forest. He skids into a small po of horrible goo. He sinks up to his waist. The puddle is covered with THE BODIES OF LARGE, DEAD FLIES.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Help! Quicksand! Ron begins to struggle helplessly in the mire. The other kids dart out from behind their cover and run to the edge of the pond of goo. ASHES CONTINUE TO FALL.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That can't be quicksand. Ron struggles, glancing around him. He lifts up a hand an puts it to his mouth. He tastes the goop.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Help! Syrup! AMY (puzzled) How did syrup get in our yard?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Never mind, Never mind. He squirms around, singing further into the mush.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Don't move. The more you move, the faster you'll sink. Don tries to stick his arm towards his brother, It won't reach. He almost topples into the pond himself. Nick grab his legs and pulls him back.. THE ASHES STILL FALL.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: We'll make a rope. We'll pull you out. Keep calm,

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 69
dialogues.text: Ron lies in the syrup. He is slowly sinking. His teeth ar chattering. He is beginning to sob; breathless little boy terrified gasps. RON (softly, shaky) Hurry. Please hurry. He slowly turns his head to the left. The body of a half- fly floats, half~submerged, in the goop. The fly is still buzzing half-heartedly. Ron is really scared. He turns hi head away from the fly and looks at something else. Anyth else. The kids are tearing at grass fibers, tying them together

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD/FENCE, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Big Russ inhales on his cigarette, still watching the Szalinskis. He takes one, last puff before tossing the cigarette into the Szalinski yard and moving closer to Wayne and Diane for a better look.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Down below, the kids are trying to toss their newly-made rope towards Ron. They keep on falling short of their mar

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: More rope! Nick peels a strand of grass off a stalk. A ROARING, WHOOSHING NOISE REVERBERATES ALL AROUND THEM. LITTLE RUSS (looking up) What the heck was that? The kids take off in every direction as THE GLOWING,

dialogues.speaker: BURNED TO DEATH WITHIN MINUTES.
dialogues.text: He begins to struggle. He sinks further. The kids run forward, trying to shield themselves from the heat.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: We have to push it away. The kids pick up a stick and move to the edge of the syru pool. They extend the stick, trying to prod the butt away from the petrified Ron. The stick doesn't reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oe Help!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: What'11 we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LANDING IN THE SYRUP NEAR THE KIDS. The kids back off, | holding their hands in front of their faces AS THE ASHE

dialogues.speaker: SINKS BENEATH THE SURFACE OF THE GOOP.
dialogues.text: Nick stares at Ron. He slowly backs away from the scene, seemingly horrified. He turns and runs full-tilt back int the forest. Amy notices but is concentrating too much on Ron's safety to act.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Please! Help me, please! Ron spots Nick running off.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Don't leave me, please! co . The children continue to try to get nearer to Ron. T se a crunching sound behind them. THEY TURN AND SEE THE L

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Come on, boy. Come on. Nick leads the ant to the edge of the bog. He slides off ant, takes the crumb and tosses it to Ron.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Ron! Catch! Ron reaches for the soggy oreo fragment and ensnares it. glimmer of hope plays across his face.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I read you, baby-brain. He turns to the ant.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You! Here you go, boy. Come and get it. Cy THE ANT EXTENDS ITS ANTENNAE. IT HONES IN ON THE OREO a THE CIGARETTE CONTINUES TO SMOLDER. THE FIRE IS GETTING CLOSER TO RON. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron drops the crumb in the syrup. The kids gasp as it disappears beneath the goop. Ron looks helplessly up at t ant. THE ANT TWITCHES ITS ANTENNAE. IT CAN'T SENSE THE CR ANYMORE.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. The kids run up to Ron. Don stares at the ant.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: He saved your life.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Even when you dropped the crumb. RON (genuinely moved) Yeah, He could've gotten wasted by the cigarette butt, same as me. He stares at the ant. The kids take turns patting the ant

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Okay, boy. You're free, It's time for you to go back home.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah. Your parents are probably worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Like ours. Russ and Amy approach the ant. Amy extends a hesitant han towards the "bug." She pets it. It twitches its antennae.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I don't know if you can understand me or not, but from now on, I'm going to be good to bugs.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Even mosquitos?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Except mosquitos. THE ANT SHAMBLES OFF INTO THE FOREST. RON (to Nick) Thanks for the help, baby—-brain... I mean, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No problem, scout. Ron grins at Nick. Nick offers a shy smile.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, Wayne and Diane continue sifting through the b of grass. They find nothing. They look at each other sadl There's a noise behind them. They turn and train the flashlight at the garbage. Cicero the cat sits there, a p of discarded, egg-stained toast in its mouth. Diane gasps The cat takes the toast and runs off. Wayne sighs.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: We still have a bag left.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I-I can't.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: There's still hope. Come on. Shine the light over here. Suddenly, the last bag is illuminated by a bright light f behind them. Big Russ stands at the fence with a Kong-siz flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Lose something, folks? Diane and Wayne exchange guilty looks.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: If I show you something...something really strange...will you promise not to get upset?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oy : BIG RUSS Me? Get upset? Heck. I’m as cool, calm and collected as they come.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Come on up to my lab.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Lab?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Uh, attic.

dialogues.speaker: EXT, FOREST/YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Ron, covered with syrup, walks over to a puddle of sprink water,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Help me waah some of this off, willya? Don steps into the puddle and begins splashing his brothe Amy and Russ begin doing the same.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I’m pooped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Maybe we should rest for the night. AMY (nodding) We have a lot of ground to cover tomorrow...I think. Nick wanders off. THE CAMERA follows him. He comes to a h smiling.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey, come look, The kids trot over to Nick.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Stretching before Nick are a few, Stonehenge~sized monoli atructures,

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: What are those? se NICK My legos.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 74
dialogues.text: The kids wander up to the titanic plastic blocks. They ar square with station-wagon-sized round indentations on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i Nick sits in one of the round indentations,

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Pretty cozy. The twins climb into two ajoining round spots.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Not bad.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: It's better than a tent.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Get some sleep now, okay?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No problem. Russ and Amy walk over to another Lego, They sit on the square end of one. They are both exhausted. They gaze up a picture perfect, clear sky. A full moon shines down on them, illuminating the area in a magical, blue glow.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Tired?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I'm okay.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I'm so sleepy, I ache. AMY (smiling) Me, too, He stifles a yawn. Amy continues to gaze at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Great moon.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's pretty full.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It's funny, The moon looks the same whether you're big or small. \ ) Russ nods. He looks at Amy, smiling shyly.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: You want to hear something stupid?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Sure. I enjoy stupid things.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Well, I've wanted to talk to you sometimes but I've felt weird because well, you're....uh...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Taller?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Yeah. Dumb, huh?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Well, it doesn't make much difference now, does it? What's the big deal if you're a quarter of an inch tall or three sixteenths?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Yeah. He suddenly turns and gives her a peck on the cheek. She towards him and gives him a brief, but tender, first kiss

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOREST/YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: We see the tiny kids illuminated from above by the pale b light of a full moon. The CAMERA slowly moves up and away from them, taking the whole, titanic yard into view.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Big Russ stands next to Wayne and Diane at the machine.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Nice CB set. WAYNE (flipping knobs and switches) Russ, the world of science is a mysterious, complex one....

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Is this going to take long?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Each and every one of us is made up of countless, tiny particles which move around and....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get to the point. Get to the point!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: And what this machine does is analyze the molecular structure of...

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Szalinskil! Wayne gulps and sighs and blurts it out.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I think this machine shrunk our kids.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: This machine. I think it shrunk our kids. Big Russ begins to laugh. He looks at Diane. She's not laughing. He looks at Wayne. Wayne slowly shakes his head yes.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: What do you take me for, a complete idiot?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: But it's true...I mean, about the machine.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: We have proof. Diane places the tiny couch in Big Russ’ hand.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: So what? A toy? Big deal. That doesn't mean our kids have shrunk. WAYNE (adjusting the gizmo) I'1l show you, Put your cap on that pedestal. BIG RUSS (aghast) My Olympian cap?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. You want proof, don't you? Russ slowly lifts the hat from his head, He is inundated a shower of cigarettes. He gazes at his hat nervously,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oN :

dialogues.speaker: SF BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: ~ I've had this cap for twenty years. Wayne gets the machine humming. Big Russ gingerly places the cap on the pedestal in front of the metal wall.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Okay. Step back and be amazed. Wayne activates the machine. BOTH BEAMS SKITTER ACROSS TH ROOM. Big Russ is not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Big deal. I have a lava light at home that works better.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Watch when the beams connect. Diane and Big Russ watch AS THE TWO BEAMS HONE IN ON THE

dialogues.speaker: SENDING BITS AND PIECES OF CHARRED MATERIAL EVERYWHERE,
dialogues.text: Diane gasps in horror. Wayne is perplexed. Big Russ is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I don’t understand it. It must have worked before....

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Are you saying my kids...that machine... you blew up my kids?! He makes a move to strangle Wayne. Wayne, ignoring lungin Big Russ, walks over to the cap fragments.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Of course not. If they had blown up, we would have found... Diane gasps.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I mean. No. They shrunk. I'm positive.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: And I'm positive that you should be locked up. I don't know what your game is, Szalinski. But if I find out that you've done anything to my kids...I'1l do to you what you did to my genuine number-one-in- a-series Olympian Construction Cap. He makes a move to stalk out of the room. He glances nervously at the floor and tip-toes carefully out, starin this way and that at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wayne stares at the machine sadly. Diane gently walks up to him and puts his arm around hin, She gives him a gentle squeeze.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: How about a drink? Wayne nods "yes," and the two leave the attic.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, NIGHT
dialogues.text: Wayne sits at the kitchen table, a half-filled glass of m before him. Wayne fingers the magnifying glass absent-min ly. Diane toys with the flashlight. Wayne smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It's all my fault. It's all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: No. You're just dedicated. I should have understood that. You have dreams.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: But I forget reality. I ignore the people I care about the most. . DIANE . Oh, Wayne. How could I have left you and the kids...if anything happens to them.... Wayne places the magnifying glass softly on the table top Diane lays down the flashlight. They sit in silence for a long minute. Tears begin to roll down Diane's face. Wayne pulls his chair next to hers and puts a protective arm around her. He knocks over a salt shaker in the process.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: We'll find them, hon. I promise. We'll find them. Diane places her head against his chest and cries. Wayne swallows hard, wipes a single tear from one eye and hugs her closer. Silence. Still tethered next to his dog bed, Quark sighs.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, NIGHT
dialogues.text: We see the light from the kitchen window. WE SLOWLY MOVE

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The scene gradually brightens. Morning has come. We now s that the children have made it all the way to the yard's edge. They are nestled in the Lego toys that Nick had dropped there the day before. In the background, the Szalinski home stands, as tall as a glacier. Russ wakes up first. He stretches, yawns, opens his eyes and turn around.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. AMY (waking up) What? Amy turns. They are only yards away from the house. She squeals with delight and gives Russ a big hug. AMY (running off) Nick! Twins! Come on! We're home! The three younger children wake up, lazily.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Wuzzat? Nick spots the house and grins.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: All right!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yahoo!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids run to the end of the yard, They run towards the first step leading to the back door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: They slow their pace and gradually come to a halt. Their faces are glum.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Uh, it's a little bigger than I thought it would be.

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES
dialogues.text: He frantically with, He finds like a ladder. ladder against 80 looks around for something to scale the step a small twig. He places it against the step It's pathetically small, like placing a step- a skyscraper. The rest of the children look on nervously.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I'll figure something out. Amy's lower lip begins to quiver. Russ tries to cheer her Tears begin to

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Don't worry. We'll make it. We just have to come up with a plan. dribble, silently, down Amy's face. The twins and Nick exchange frightened glances. This is t first time Amy has really acted like a (gasp) girl. Nick approaches her. He kneels next to her. Amy sniffs and Nick stands up

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Amy? Don't cry. Amy? Come on. Even if the odds are against us, so what? People beat the odds all the time, right?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Sure. We've gotten this far.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Yeah, We've gotten through a flood.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: And killer bees.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: And a power mower.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: And maple syrup! nods, only half believing.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: But how will we get inside the house? suddenly. He stares at the door and smiles. He has an idea, Placing two fingers in his mouth, he emit a shrill whistle. He's winded after one try. Wheeze. Whee

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loo NICK ~ Hitching a ride. He puffs out his little chest again and lets out a second shrill blast.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: In the kitchen, Wayne and Diane are sound asleep at the table. Quark is still tethered. He hears a very faint, ve familiar whistle. His ears perk up. It's Nick. Quark begi to whine and pull at the leash. He can't get out. Another whistle. He gnaws at his leash. It's too thick.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Nick's face is now beet red. He whistles again.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Quark will never hear you.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Sure he will. Dogs have great ears. Russ and the twins exchange glances. They shrug. They beg ce whistling and shouting. a LITTLE RUSS Here, boy.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yo, dog!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Wake up!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Hey, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark stops gnawing at his leash. He turns himself around and slowly pulls himself, backwards, out of his dog colla He runs for the swinging door leading outside. He can't budge it. He pushes and pushes and pushes again. The kids outside are still whistling and yelling. Quark pushes. No dice. Finally, Quark backs up waaaay across the kitchen a charges the door, He hurls himself onto its surface. The door flies open, staying in that position.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids scatter as Quark goes tumbling down the stairs. Quark gets to his feet and stands, puzzled. We watch the dog's startled expression as he registers tiny, invisible

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 82
dialogues.text: CY) voices all around him.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Good boy, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Over here, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Atta way, dog. Quark turns this way and that, trying to find his masters Finally, he zeroes in on the source of the sound. He cautiously approaches a spot on the ground. He stares at the teeny-weeny youngsters. He lets out a small whimper.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's us, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We're just littler, now. Quark does a "say what?" take,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Lie down, Quark. Lie down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quark begins to sniff at the kids. They are almost sucked up his nostrils.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Don't sniff, dumb-bell. Lie down. Quark does as he is told.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Stay, Quark. Stay.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: All aboard, The dog whimpers slightly as the barely larger-than-flea sized kids climb up his ear and onto the back of his head

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOG, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids hold onto Quark's head.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Phew. Quark needs a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i } Everybody on?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Ready for take-off.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Okay, Quark. Get up. Come ‘on, boy. Get up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark gets to his feet. AMY (v.0.) Inside, Quark. Take us inside. Instinctively, Quark sits down and, with his rear leg, scratches his head as if he were in pursuit of fleas.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOG, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids hang on for dear life as the skin beneath them shimmies and a large paw rakes the surface behind them,

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Cut it out, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Knock it off!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: The dog whimpers and stops scratching. Quark stands up. AMY (v.0.) Come on, Quark. Up the steps. Into the house. Quark takes the first step and stops. He turns to the rig The Johnson's cat is there, hissing. Quark growls. LITTLE RUSS (v.0.) Oh, no. It's Cicero. RON (0.s.) I've always hated that cat. AMY (v.0.) Quark. Up the stairs, boy. Don't chase the cat. Quark looks as if he's going to chase Cicero. The cat is bigger than the dog, however, and lunges after the tiny canine. Quark, panicked, takes off. He runs to the back o

dialogues.speaker: THE TEENY-WEENIES 84
dialogues.text: yard, Cicero in pursuit. KIDS (v.o0.) Whoaaaah! Quark hits the trash bags and wriggles under the fence. T cat chasing him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOG, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids yell as Quark takes them on a wild ride.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark darts into the street. He's a yard dog and totally panics when outside his turf. As soon as Quark darts into street, Cicero skids to a stop, curbside, and watches wid eyed as the dog skitters around in traffic. Quark zig-zag and down the street, in and out of traffic, yelping.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOG, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids scream as titanic cars and people pass them by. blare. Tires screech. People yell. It's like being caught an out-of-control plane zipping through the canyons of Ne York City.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Whoa, Quark. Whoah!

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Look out! We see a titanic car bearing down on the dog from one sid Little Russ spins around and points. There's a car approa from the other side, too.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET, DAY
dialogues.text: We see Quark, paralyzed with fear, as the two cars come speeding towards him from both sides. The dog doesn't mov Quark lays down in the street and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOG, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids dive down on Quark's head as deafening screeches horns shake the sky. They close their eyes. CRAASSSHHHHH!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark opens his eyes and gets up. The two cars have crash and are suspended, pyramid style, above him. The two driv are screaming at each other from inside the car, Quark tr away. He passes by the amazed Cicero with a “snort.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: d NICK (v.o.) Way to go, Quark.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark squeezes under the fence into the backyard and leap the steps leading to the back door.

dialogues.speaker: CHILDREN
dialogues.text: Whoaaaaaahhhh!

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark skids into the kitchen, AMY (v.0.) Go get dad, Quark. Go to dad. Quark trots over to the sleeping Wayne's leg. He nuzzles the leg and whines. Wayne snores a bit and, still asleep, Swats his leg with his hand. The kids yelp as Quark backs . up. NICK (v.0.) We'll get killed that way. oe LITTLE RUSS (v.0.) pos Let's try yelling.

dialogues.speaker: WD
dialogues.text: ™ KIDS (v.0.) Mom! Dad! KIDS (v.0.) Mr. Szalinski! Yo, Prof! Wayne and Diane continue to sleep. Quark stands before them, puzzled. NICK (v.o0.) They can't see us from here. LITTLE RUSS (v.0.) They can't hear us, either. RON (v.0.) They'd see us from the kitchen table. AMY (v.0.) Good idea. Quark. Up on the table, boy. The little dog cocks its head and, obediently, stands on its hind legs, trying to get up on the table. He's too short.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOG, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids are sliding off his head.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Down, Quark. Get down! The dog's head straightens as he slides off the table leg Russ scans the room.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We have to get on that table somehow. NICK (pointing) Quark can drop us off there. He points to the shorter, more accessable sewing stool standing less than a foot from the kitchen table.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Take us to the sewing table, Quark. Over there, boy. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark trots over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEWING TABLE, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids leap off the dog and stand on the table. The kitchen table looms before them, a mammoth chasm separati the two pieces of furniture.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Great. Now all we need is a helicopter.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Can we throw things at them to wake them up?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: What are we going to throw? Ron points to a thimble, four times his size.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Want to try chucking this, Hercules?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Cut it out. We'll think of something. Russ roams around the sewing table. Even the regular-size needles are titanic, He comes across a small, portable se kit: the kind you buy in a five and dime store or get for in a hotel. It consists of a small envelope, a few tiny b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ld tons and needles 1/4 the size of your everyday, househ needles, Russ picks up one of the small needles by one end. It's f too big to throw.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Can you throw it?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Not a chance. He begins prowling around again, All the kids do. Nick trips over a small rubber band. Russ grins.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Maybe we can shoot it, though. Ron grabs the rubber band,

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Not a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: This genius stuff is spreading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russ takes a small spool of thread and places a strand of thread through the needle. He hooks one end of the thread to a splinter in the table-top, anchoring it. He then mak sure that the spool holding the rest of the thread is jammed tightly down on a large needle stuck into a pin cushion in the sewing kit.

dialogues.speaker: . LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: This ought to hold. Maybe we can shoot this thing at your dad. If we hit hin, he's sure to wake up and spot us.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Suppose we miss? Little Russ points to the way the needle is threaded.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: It's like a harpoon. If we miss, we pull it back and try again....I hope. Russ walks up to the rubber band, puzzling over it. He tr to stretch it between the points of a scissor. It pops of DON (looking at a nearby spool) We can make a spool cannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a small spool of thread and rolls it on its side front of the rubber band. The kids take the rubber band a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vo stretch it around the spool. Russ takes the needle and ° places it inside the round cylinder. The kids hold the side of the spool. Russ grabs the end o the needle, places it against the rubber band strung arou the spool and, slowly, pulls the needle back. Further. Further. Finally, it's 75% out of the cannon muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Great idea. He peeks through the "spool barrel" of the cannon. The ot kids take their places on either side of the spool. He peeks through the "spool barrel" of the cannon. The ot kids take their places on either side of the spool.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: A little to the left. The kids push the spool.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: A little more. A little...perfect. . LITTLE RUSS (straining) co Ready. Aim. Fireli!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lets the needle go.

dialogues.speaker: INT, KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: The rubber band recoils with a spronnnng. The needle soar towards the table, the spool of thread it's affixed to whirling madly.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: The needle goes sailing past Wayne and winds up embedding itself in an orange resting in a fruit dish in the middle the table. Sploosh.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SEWING TABLE, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids stare at the far off orange.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: We're sunk.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: No we're not. Let's just pull it back. i D They tug on the thread, trying to dislodge the needle — orange. It won't budget. As one, the children stop yank the thread, Lo ety

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we're sunk, They gaze at the kitchen table. It's only one or two norm sized feet away but a good mile or so from the kids' poin view. Spanning the chasm between the sewing stool and the kitchen table are two strands of thread, hooked into the needle, Nick "“twangs" the thread. It quivers but seems v very solid. LITTLE RUSS (smiling at Nick) Ever gone tightrope walking? NICK (nervously) No. Russ trots over to the spool of thread still attached to the needle. He pulls the thread taut around another needl causing the newly formed rope bridge to tighten. He then walks over to the edge of the sewing table.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: The only we're going to get onto that table is to climb over.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Like on a rope bridge?

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Right. Like in scouts. Ron looks at the linoleum floor miles below them.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: No offense, but in scouts,they never asked us to climb over the Grand Canyon.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: You have a better idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Russell, Nick will never make it. NICK (defiantly) Yes I will. LITTLE RUSS (thoughtfully) Amy might be right, Nick. We can wake up your dad and come back for you here. NICK (bristling) No way. We all go together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ron and Don pat Nick on the back.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Way to go, scout. DON (to others) He'll make it. No sweat. Russ looks at the double stranded rope bridge before then

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: I'll go first, The trick is to move slowly and evenly. He gets on the rope bridge, grabbing the top strand of th thread with his hands and sliding his feet onto the botto strand.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: We won't be climbing as much as pulling ourselves across. Understand? The kids nod. They're scared stiff.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's go. Ge Amy gets on the rope bridge next. Her knees almost buckle as the bottom strand wiggles under her weight.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Easy. Don't be afraid. Just hold on tight with your hands. That's it. The twins are next on. Ron gulps, looks down at the dizzy view, grits his teeth and climbs on. Don takes a deep breath and does the same,

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I. wish I was home watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: You and me both. Nick stands on the edge of the table. He gapes at the flo far below and, then, at the kitchen table standing, tow- ering, at the other end of the bridge. He glances at Quar Quark cocks his head, flattens his ears and whines.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I know just how you feel, 4 Nick takes a deep breath and gets on the bridge. He shu his eyes for a moment and exhales.

dialogues.speaker: INT, KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: The thread wobbles constantly as the teeny-weenies slowly inch their way across the rope bridge.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Slow and steady. Fine. Fine. Can you all say that? Slow and steady . and slow and steady. The kids begin to chant "slow and steady" as they rhythmically work their way across the bridge. The bridge begins to tilt upwards towards the table top. THE CAMERA slowly pans across the frightened faces of the children a they chant and begin the trek upwards for the last fiftee inches or so...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TABLE, DAY
dialogues.text: We see a slight tug on the thread attached to the needle. needle, still embedded in the orange, begins to jiggle slightly. Wayne and Diane sit, sleeping at the table.

dialogues.speaker: INT, KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark sits in the corner, amazed at the goings on.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Still chanting "slow and steady," the kids continue their crossing. Suddenly, Amy loses her footing. She shrieks, h feet dangling in the air,

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Just hang on! Hang on! She desperately tries to get her feet back on the bottom strand of thread. Her lack of balance causes the other ki to sway dangerously on the thread, The kids shout as they try to steady themselves, Slowly, Amy regains her footing

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I've been better.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Okay. We're almost there. Slow and steady. Everybody. Slow and steady. The thread suddenly begins to quiver.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: What's wrong? LITTLE RUSS (alarmed) I don't know. Come on. Faster. Fast and steady. Fast and steady.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Make up your mind!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TABLE, DAY
dialogues.text: On the table top, we see that the needle-anchor is beginn to work itself loose from the orange in a big way. Each t on the thread caused by the kids' feet and hands is makin needle wriggle more.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids are pulling themselves upward for their lives. They are a mere inch or two from the table top. The threa is jiggling madly now,

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Come on! Hurry!

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I don't like this!

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: You think I do? Nick can't speak. He's wheezing, now, pulling his own wei furiously. He begins to gasp. The other kids turn and sta Nick launches into a full tilt asthma attack. He desperat reaches into his pocket for his inhaler. He produces it b tumbles out of his hand, tumbling towards the floor far b He is gasping for breath. His face is red. Russ turns towards him.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: Nick, you don't need that junk. You're going to be all right. Take deep, steady breaths. Okay? Try it. Slowly. Nick begins breathing in and out, in and out, in and out. Gradually, he stops gasping.

dialogues.speaker: RUSS
dialogues.text: Better? Nick nods his head. He is scared stiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The floor seems to sway below the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue to.climb.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TABLE, DAY
dialogues.text: The needle continues to wriggle.

dialogues.speaker: INT, KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Russ is within a hair of the table top when....

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TABLE TOP, DAY
dialogues.text: The pin sprongs loose from the orange. The needle begins slide across the table.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Russ holds desperately onto the edge of the table as the thread goes limp. The kids lose their footing and cling t the thread as it drops down like an elevator sans shaft. The needle zips along the table top, coming to an abrupt as it hits the lip of the table and gets wedged in the formica. Russ climbs ontop of the table and grabs the thr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on! Hold on! Amy, Ron, Don and Nick cling to the thread. Russ begins t pull the thread taut, using every ounce of his strength.

dialogues.speaker: . LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Try to climb! Try! Russ clings desperately to the thread, holding it as tightly as he can. He puts all his weight behind it. On-the thread, the remaining children have to climb, hand over hand up the thread, wrapping their legs around the lone, taut strand, Amy gets to the top of the table and pulls herself up and over. She leans down and grabs Ron. She pulls Ron up. Rus holds the thread desperately. Ron pulis Don up. Now, the only child remaining, dangling from the needle i Nick.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Come on. Grab the thread. { ) Ron and Don grab the thread and, with their brother, it taut. Amy grabs on and pulls back, trying to give Nick every advantage. Amy, the closest to the edge of the tabl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: gazes down at Nick, terrified. In spite of the tautness o the thread, she doesn't think the little boy will make it AMY (to the boys) Can you handle this thread? Russ and the twins nod "yes," straining. Amy, still holdi the thread, calls down to Nick,

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Nick. Stay there. I'm coming down to get you. Nick stares at the table top above hin. NICK (wheezing) No. I can do it. I can do it... by myself, Nick slowly, laboriously, begins to shinny up the taut thread, Hand over hand over hand. Knees wrapped tightly around the thread. Hand over hand. Knee up. Knee up. Amy watches silently as Nick grimly continues his ascent. AMY (to Russ) He'll never do it.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Sure he will. Come on, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: RON/DON
dialogues.text: Come on, Nick. Come on. | With the boys chanting for him to "make it," Nick pushes upward. His face is red with exhaustion. His forehead is mass of sweat droplets. He climbs and climbs and, then, s He.is an inch away from the table top, the kids all cheering him on. Nick gazes down at the floor below hin. The view is dizzying. He sees Amy's worried face above him. Taking a deep, whee breath, he begins to climb again. Finally, he makes it to table top. Amy extends a hand and pulls him up and onto t top. Don, Ron and Russ let the thread go and run towards littl Nick. The needle becomes unstuck and zips by them and ove the edge of the table. It tumbles, in seemingly slow motion, towards the floor below. The kids surround Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: uf NICK. (wheezing) I told you I could do it.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: So, who said you couldn't?

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: I knew you could do it all along. Russ winks at Nick. Nick shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Let's get dad.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TABLE TOP, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids run across the vast expanse of the table and sta in front of the slumbering parents. They walk up to Wayne whose head is on the table, and yell into his ear.

dialogues.speaker: AMY/NICK
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Mr. and Mrs. Szalinski! ca RON

dialogues.speaker: J
dialogues.text: ~~ Yo! Over here! No response. THe sleeping parents still sit, mountain-lik in their chairs.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Forget it. They can't hear us.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: I wish we still had that needle, I'd jam it in...

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: We'll never wake them up.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: And when they do wake up, they'll need a neon sign to see us, Nick gazes glumly at the table top. He sees the mound of salt Wayne has spilled the night before. He gazes at it. Nick turns to Ron and Don.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Q } When explorers get lost in the snow, a they make snow signs, right?

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Yeah? He points to the salt.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: A salt sign? The kids turn and focus on the mound of salt. Ron smiles, pointing to the abandoned magnifying glass.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: That ought to help, too.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Lion scouts to the rescue. Ron and Don and run to the salt mound and begin laborious fashioning a large arrow leading to the magnifying glass. LITTLE RUSS (smiling) Sometimes I'm almost proud of those guys. Russ, Amy and Nick join in the construction of the arrow. The finished work is some three inches long, the arrow "head" pointing to the magnifying glass. Once the arrow is finished, the kids all huddle beneath t magnifying glass.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: When dad wakes up, he'll have to see us.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: They look pretty tired. They could sleep all day.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Quark. Hey, Quark. Wanna eat?

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Quark, hearing the tiny but distinct voice, wags his tail He runs to the food bowl. There's no food there. The dog turns, puzzled, towards the table. NICK (v.0.) Chow time, Quark. The dog begins to bark. Wayne stirs slightly. Quark begin to whine and bark again, circling his empty bowl. Wayne's eyes flutter.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TABLE TOP, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids watch Wayne slowly awaken.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: All right. You're dad's waking up.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Everybody move around.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Shake it. The kids begin to dance and wave under the magnifying gla Wayne wakes up and launches into his habitual morning sne A sudden gale of wind blows across the table top.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Hold on. The kids cling to each other as they are buffeted by the wind. Half of the salt arrow is blown away.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne stretches.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Not now, Quark. He gets up to leave the table when Quark suddenly leaps onto his lap and, then, onto the table. DIANE (waking) What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Quark's going bonkers. Wayne turns and is about to yell at the dog when he spots the remainder of the arrow and, then, the magnifying glas

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TABLE TOP, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne gapes at the dancing kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my god. DIANE (spotting the glass) What?...What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WAYNE (near tears) You're alive! You're safe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NF The kids continue to wave and yell. Diane leans down towards them,

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Thank god they're all right. RON (even though he can't be heard) You should have seen us ten minutes ago! She makes a move to grab the kids. They duck, Wayne restrains her.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Don't touch then. She pulls her hand back.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: They're too small to handle. We may hurt them.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: That's right. He faces the kids, gently lifting up the magnifying glass

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Don't worry, guys. You're safe now, Wait right there. The twins look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Where does he expect us to go? Amy hugs Russ.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE RUSS
dialogues.text: Everything is going to be all right, now. Nick smiles, collapsing into a sitting position. Phew! Wayne brings a spoon over to the table and sets it down next to the children. |

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Can you make it up here? Nick is the first one to leap into the spoon.

dialogues.speaker: . NICK
dialogues.text: oo Come on, slowpokes. Russ and Amy share an amused grin and climb into the spoo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The twins follow with a whoop.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SPOON, DAY
dialogues.text: Wayne carefully lifts the spoon.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN, DAY
dialogues.text: He heads for the stairs leading up to the attic. . WAYNE (to Diane) Get the Johnsons over here. I'11 warm up the machine. Quark leaps off the table and follows. AMY (from the spoon) You're a hero, Quark. That was a two milkbone move, The dog wags its tail merrily.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: In the attic, Wayne carefully places the spoon in the tar area of the room while Diane holds Quark in her arms. A os stricken Mae Johnson stands nervously next to her, lin ~— arm in Diane's. Big Russ is dumbfounded and, as usual,

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: You're a maniac, Szalinski. Do you realize what you've done? They're ruined for life!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I have the atomic makeup computed. Wayne adjusts the computer, focusing it on the children.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: If you hurt them any more, Szalinski, I'11 personally re-do your house with my bulldozer!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Now, I have to figure the amount of space needed to be placed between their atoms.

dialogues.speaker: MAE
dialogues.text: Please hurry.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: It's done. Now, to add an extra dollop } of energy, to replace the energy they NA lost when shrinking....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a move to turn on the machine, Big Russ tenses.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: If you blow them up.... Wayne withdraws his arn,

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: He has a point. I haven't gotten the machine to work properly. But the kids have,

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC FLOOR, DAY
dialogues.text: The kids stare at each other, confused.

dialogues.speaker: RON
dialogues.text: Some genius.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Give him time. He'll figure something out.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
dialogues.text: WAYNE (scratching his head) Somehow, the kids stumbled onto something that I've been overlooking, He then notices the twins’ baseball still resting on the floor. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Russ, toss me that ball?

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: I oughtta bean you with this ball. He picks up the baseball and tosses it to Wayne. Wayne studies it. He gazes at the burn mark on the ball. He the makes some adjustments in the machinery.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: The answer has been right under my nose all along.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: You like baseball.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: The machine uses two beams, a laser tracking beam and the actual shrinking beam. The tracking beam focuses the second beam on the target. The reason things have been blowing up instead of shrinking is that, when the beams collide, they generate too much heat. Yesterday, this ball must have blocked the tracking beam. The shrinking beam worked all on its own. Now, all I have to do is shut off the one beam... He throws the switch into "on" position again. THE MACHIN

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Let's see if it works. I need a a target.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: You already blew up my hat. Wayne looks about. He realizes he still has the ball in h hand. He tosses the ball before the beams. THE BALL IS

dialogues.speaker: ZAPPED AND MINATURIZES. THE TINY BALL FALLS NEXT TO THE
dialogues.text: CHILDREN. Nick turns to Ron.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I told you he'd figure it out. Big Russ is impressed. He turns to Mae.

dialogues.speaker: BIG RUSS
dialogues.text: Did you see that?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Now, all I have to do is reverse the polarity of the beam and...add some energy.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Come on. You can do it. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: This way! No, over here! There it goes! Get it!

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC, DAY
